light passed through four prisms.
61. In sending the direct discharge of 
Ruhmkorff’s coil through a tube of glass 
from 1/4 to 1/8 of an inch in diameter,
provided with electrodes of platinum or 
of aluminium enclosing Hydrogen at a 
tension of 5 to 10mm a luminous threath 
of light of a bluisch-white colour was 
seen passing along the axis of the tube,
without touching the glass. When analysed 
by the prism, it gave a faint spectrum of 
the above mentioned numerous <s>lum<\s> bright 
lines, especially within the red and the 
yellow. Among these lines neither H[alpha] nor 
H[gamma] were seen, H[beta] only appeared, but less 
bright than many of the other lines. By 
interposing the Leyden jar and gradually 
increasing its charge (12), all lines became 
brighter, H[beta] surpassing all other lines in 
brilliancy; H[alpha] appeared beautifully, H[gamma] fainter.
Hence we conclude that the numerous bright 
lines belong neither to the vaporised metal 
of the electrodes, nor to the decomposed in 
terior surface of the glass, but solely to the 
hydrogen, constituiting a new spectrum 
of it. This spectrum may be seen simul 
taneously with the three characteristic 
lines H[alpha], H[beta], H[gamma]; but, at an increased tem 
perature, when these lines begin to expand,
it entirely disappears.
62. We got only one spectrum of <u>Oxygen<\u>
